title: Nepal Protest Live Updates: Gen Z activists demand parliament dissolution, constitutional amendment
body: Nepal Protest Live Updates: Kathmandu dropped as neutral venue for Blind T20 CWC for women Grieving families of protesters killed in Nepal seek justice as some people try to leave Families of protesters killed in recent clashes in Nepal gathered in the capital on Thursday, holding a candlelight vigil outside a hospital morgue. They demanded answers about missing relatives and vowed to seek justice in a meeting with army officials. The unrest, which erupted earlier this week, has left 34 people dead and more than 1,300 injured, according to Nepal’s Health Ministry. The protests began over a brief social media ban but quickly swelled into wider anger over corruption and unemployment. Earlier on Tuesday night, Nepal’s army seized control of Kathmandu after demonstrators set fire to government buildings and the presidential residence, forcing the prime minister to resign and flee. Meanwhile, chaos gripped the main airport as hundreds tried to leave the country amid uncertainty over who will lead the nation. Nepal Protest Live Updates: Erstwhile King Gyanendra Shah appeals for calm amid political turmoil in the country Erstwhile King Gyanendra Shah appealed for calm amid Nepal’s political turmoil, saying "the recent violence, arson, and vandalism during public demonstrations, which caused significant human and material losses, have deeply saddened us. No system or ideology is greater than civic freedom." Nepal unrest: 23 stranded Odias rescued and brought back to India, says Odisha CM Mohan Charan Majhi 144 Telugu people airlifted from Nepal to Vizag, Tirupati by special flight Andhra Pradesh IT Minister Nara Lokesh on Thursday said 144 Telugu people were safely airlifted from Kathmandu in a special flight to Visakhapatnam and Tirupati. Gen Z group demands to dissolve Parliament, amend constitution Youth-led Gen Z group, which spearheaded the anti-government protests in Nepal, Thursday said that Parliament must be dissolved and the Constitution should be amended to reflect the will of the people, as the death toll from the demonstrations increased to 34. 'Will reach out to MEA to ensure safety of Indian citizens': Supriya Sule On anti-corruption protests in Nepal, NCP-SCP MP Supriya Sule said, "I'll reach out to the MEA to ensure the safety of the Indian citizens. I also propose an all-party meet & 5-day special session." Meanwhile, BJP MP Anurag Thakur said, "Government of India is taking all appropriate measures to evacuate and save Indian nationals. Ministry of External Affairs (MEA) is sharing details on this from time to time. We want peace in Nepal and that there should be no loss of life or property. We have a 'Roti-Beti' relation with Nepal, we have trade relations. In a way, they are a part of our family." Gen Z leaders hold talks with president at Army HQ for interim govt formation Representatives of the protesting 'Gen Z' group, Nepalese President Ramchandra Paudel and Army Chief Ashok Raj Sigdel were holding talks at the army headquarters in Bhadrakali on Thursday to pick a leader to run an interim government, sources said. Former chief justice Sushila Karki, Kathmandu Mayor Balendra Shah and two others were among those being considered by the protesting Gen Z group to lead the interim government, they added. The interim leader will replace Prime Minister K P Sharma Oli, who resigned on Tuesday following a violent student-led agitation. An Army spokesperson confirmed that discussions are ongoing with various stakeholders. He, however, did not provide any names. “We are holding rounds of talks with different stakeholders. The talks are mainly focused on finding a way out from the current stalemate and at the same time maintaining law and order situation in the country,” the Army spokesperson said. 'Right now, we need an interim government and proposes name of Sushila Karki': Gen Z leader Ojaswi Gen-Z leader Ojaswi says, "...Right now, we need an interim government, for which we have proposed the name of Sushila Karki...We want to choose her because she would help us build this nation...Second, dissolving the current Parliament. Third, maintaining law and order in the country..." "We don't have leaders in Gen-Z, it was something that started overnight...We don't have leaders, we all are Gen-Z, we all are leaders...Right now, we are trying to dissolve the Parliament...We are not trying to dissolve our Constitution or void our Constitution in any way. Maybe there are certain changes that need to be made in the Constitution for now. But other than that, Constitution will remain intact because Constitution needs to be there...While going forward, we should make sure that we do not take any steps that are unlawful, illegal...Right now, we need an interim government, for which we have proposed the name of Sushila Karki...Second, dissolving the current Parliament. Third, maintaining law and order in the country...Sushila Karki is very positive towards that. Our country is getting the first woman PM which is a beautiful thing...We want to choose her because she would help us build this nation..." 'It is better if Indian Government speaks on it': Fadnavis on Nepal protest On unrest in Nepal, Maharashtra CM Devendra Fadnavis says, "This is an international issue. It is better if the Government of India speaks on it. Our tourists, including those from Maharashtra, who are visiting Nepal, are being brought back. We are in touch with them." Over 150 Telugu people cleared for boarding in Nepal The Andhra Pradesh government on Thursday said over 150 Telugu people have been cleared for boarding at the Kathmandu airport, while a group of 12 from Simikot has safely entered India through Nepalganj. The state government is coordinating real-time evacuation efforts to bring back stranded Telugu people from various regions of unrest-hit Nepal, said a release from TDP. “Simikot passengers have landed in Nepalganj and crossed into India safely. In Kathmandu, 154 boarding passes have been issued, including 10 people shifted from Pokhara,” it said. Nepal president urges parties to seek swift solution to citizens’ demands The statement reads, “Respected Nepali brothers and sisters, I am making every effort to find a way out of the current difficult situation in the country within the constitutional framework and to protect democracy and maintain peace and order in the country. I appeal to all parties to be confident that a solution to the problem is being sought as soon as possible to address the demands of the agitating citizens and to cooperate with restraint in maintaining peace and order in the country.” Nepali army reports 192 prisoners apprehended after jail escape attempt in Rajbiraj According to a security update released by the Nepali army on Thursday, 192 inmates who tried to escape from the district jail in Rajbiraj, Saptari, have been caught. The report states that during the crackdown, seven escapees were detained by the Indian border security force while attempting to cross into India and were subsequently handed over to the Nepali Army. Additionally, one prisoner was captured by local residents and surrendered to the police, while twelve others voluntarily returned to the jail. SSB arrests 60 Nepal jail escapees at India-Nepal border indian officers of Sashastra Seema Bal (SSB) have apprehended 60 inmates who escaped from a Nepal jail. The fugitives were caught at various checkposts along the India-Nepal border. According to officials, all the inmates have been handed over to the local police for further action. Gen-Z leader Anil Baniya accuses political cadre for violence; says election in six months Gen-Z leader Anil Baniya said, “We did this movement after getting fed up with the old-aged leaders. We had called for a peaceful protest, but the political cadres caused the arson and then vandalised the infrastructure.” He added, “Through online surveys, the Gen-Z leaders voted for Sushila Karki. We are not trying to change the constitution, but make necessary changes to it. Within 6 months, we will head to the election.” The Health Ministry has confirmed 34 deaths linked to the Gen-Z protests on Monday and Tuesday. According to official data, 1,338 people are currently being treated in hospitals nationwide, while 949 have been discharged. The fatalities include six at Civil Hospital, Kathmandu; eight at the National Trauma Center; three at Everest Hospital; five at Bheri Hospital; three at Frontline Hospital; two each at KMC Hospital, BP Koirala Institute of Health Sciences and Bayodha Hospital; and one each at Tribhuvan University Teaching Hospital, Ilam Hospital and B&C Hospital. The ministry said it is closely tracking the situation, hospital capacities and the condition of the injured. Interim leadership talks stall over dispute about pro-monarchy party The talks over transitional civilian leadership between the gen-Z protesters and the army hit a halt on Wednesday, after the army suggested including the pro-monarchy Rastriya Swatantra Party and business Durga Prasai in the dialogue. One of the 15 gen-Z representatives, part of the dialogue, walked out objecting to the suggestion bringing it to a halt. CM Vishnu Deo Sai moves to help Chhattisgarh tourists stranded in Nepal return safely Chhattisgarh CM Vishnu Deo Sai said the state government is taking prompt steps to bring back tourists from Chhattisgarh who are stuck in Nepal amid the ongoing unrest. Death toll rises to 30 in Nepal's Gen-Z protests At least 30 people have died in Nepal amid ongoing protests led by gen-Z demonstrators demanding political reforms and a shift in leadership. The unrest has intensified across key cities, prompting security crackdowns and international concern. Calm returns to Nepal as military moves in following violent protests Soldiers were deployed across Nepal’s capital, Kathmandu, on Wednesday to restore order, as protest leaders, who had earlier pushed out the country’s prime minister, entered talks with the military. The shift marked a dramatic change for the youth-led movement, which just days earlier had clashed violently with security forces, resulting in 30 deaths and widespread damage to government buildings. Special Air India flights from Delhi to Kathmandu amid Nepal crisis In response to ongoing unrest in Nepal, Air India had announced on Wednesday, special flights between Delhi and Kathmandu on Wednesday and Thursday to assist stranded passengers. “Air India is operating special flights today and tomorrow from Delhi to Kathmandu and back to help passengers who have been stranded due to the recent developments in Nepal. Our scheduled operations will also resume from tomorrow,” the airline posted on X. They also thanked the government for “quick coordination” and advised passengers to check flight status before heading to the airport. IndiGo similarly on Wednesday, resumed operations after the reopening of Kathmandu’s Tribhuvan International Airport, which had been closed due to Gen Z-led protests. “Flight operations to and from #Kathmandu have now resumed,” the airline said on X.
